awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Nutrient Pollution, Riverine Mud Investment, and Environmental Governance
awd_abstract_narration:
The incorporation of nutrients such as nitrogen and phosphorous into agricultural fertilizing practices over the last century has enabled a dramatic increase in both the scale and efficiency of agricultural production. An additional consequence, however, has been an increase in the pressure placed upon local ecosystems to absorb the excess leaching of such nutrients from agricultural fields. This phenomenon, referred to as nutrient pollution, has notably been found to significantly threaten the health of critical freshwater supplies as excess nutrients can encourage the growth of harmful algae blooms which release harmful toxins to both human and nonhuman populations. As a result, there has been recent scientific and legal investment in riverine mud located on the periphery of industrial farmlands, which mediate the transference of nutrients from fields to waterways in critical, albeit little understood ways. This project, which supports the training of a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of empirical, scientific data collection and analysis, investigates how scientific and legal framings of riverine mud create a new tool for confronting the problem of nutrient pollution and the consequences of such a tool for local and national health and governance.

Through participant observation, interviews, focus groups, ethnographic film elicitation, archival research, and the creation of a regional-specific historical database of the social and environmental significance of riverine mud, the investigators will examine the practical, scientific, and bureaucratic work carried out by state-funded scientists and policy makers to transform riverine mud into a valuable resource for environmental governance. Following such practices across scientific field sites in farmlands near major freshwater supplies, laboratories where nutrient pollution is studied, and offices where nutrient pollution policy is created, this research aims to clarify the technical complexities of environmental governance practices more broadly. Additionally, by focusing on the specific material of riverine mud and its relation to the problem of the nutrient pollution governance practices, this research aims to better understand how specific material and historical concerns inflect contemporary state efforts to govern in ways which are both environmentally sustainable and economically viable.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project was designed to contribute to the development of novel freshwater protection and agricultural sustainability policies attuned to the social dimensions of environmental governance. More specifically, the project was designed to investigate environmental governance policies surrounding nutrient pollution related to agricultural run-off and harmful algal bloom growth in Lake Erie, both of which are related to the management of riverine mud throughout the region. Research questions based on preliminary fieldwork findings and scholarly literature in the field of cultural anthropology addressed how scientific and legal framings of riverine mud create a new tool for both confronting the problem of nutrient pollution and extending state sovereignty. By comparing contemporary valuations of riverine mud to historical orientations to mud in a region that has explicitly sought to convert muddy wetland areas into arable farmland for centuries in order to assert sovereignty over and extract value from previously inhabited land, this research also aimed to offer insights into how political orientations to matter change through time and delimit state capacities to govern both materials and citizens.  

In order to understand the social dimensions of such dynamics and their political effects, the co-investigator (co-PI) carried out ethnographic fieldwork with wetland ecologists, farmers, policy makers, and data scientists working to implement a comprehensive water-quality initiative centered on riverine mud management throughout the state of Ohio. During ethnographic fieldwork, an investigator enters a fieldsite for an extended period of time, participating in and observing the daily activities of a group of people as well as interviewing participants for research purposes. During this period, the co-PI visited over 20 wetland restoration sites throughout the state of Ohio, participated in 10 agricultural and environmental science conferences, observed over 60 research team meetings with wetland ecologists studying nutrient pollution in Lake Erie, and conducted 105 formal interviews with policy experts, engineers, farmers, scientists, and environmental activists, among other activities. Additionally, the co-PI visited local archives throughout the state to learn about historical land use practices in the region as well as prior social and political orientations to muddy terrains. 

Through this work, the co-PI came to understand the abstract notion of a ?nutrient budget? as a key legal and scientific framework through which the problem of nutrient pollution is imagined in Lake Erie. More specifically, the co-PI observed that efforts to balance Lake Erie?s ?nutrient budget? necessarily entailed the standardization of wetland management activities and farming techniques in order to strengthen the predictive capacities of watershed statistical models, which are generated from vast quantities of data produced about nutrient processes in Lake Erie?s watershed. In this way, efforts to mitigate harmful algal blooms were observed to coincide with a renewed valuation of nutrient data, which itself must be collected, organized, and analyzed in specific ways to ensure data quality across sites and epistemic frameworks. Through insights such as this, the co-PI came to understand nutrient data management and the standardization of various management activities needed to ensure nutrient data quality as critical practices through which interventions into the problem of harmful algal blooms are made. By documenting such efforts through film and written formats over the course of fieldwork, the co-PI has sought to more effectively narrativize and aesthetically frame stories about nutrient pollution and water health for audiences with varying knowledge of the technical, practical, and political specificities at play. 

The co-PI has presented such preliminary findings in both academic and public-facing conferences and will further code and interpret the data gathered over the course of fieldwork to present more-detailed findings of the study in a doctoral dissertation and research articles. The project may also culminate in the creation of a scholarly book project as well as various short-form audio-visual materials, which will be shared with the public through partnerships made over the course of fieldwork.
